tit.cmt: カッコ部分を補いました。

sen.j: きずし（生寿司、生鮨）は、青魚を塩締めしたもの。
sen.e: Kizushi refers to the salted blue-skin fish.
Kizushi refers to the salted blue-skinned fish.
Kizushi refers to the salted blue-skinned fish.

sen.j: 概ねサバであるがサワラなど他の魚を用いたものもある。
sen.e: The chub mackerel is the most common, but other fish, such as spanish mackerel, is also used.
The chub mackerel is the most common, but other fish, such as Spanish mackerel, is also used.
The chub mackerel is the most common, but other fish, such as Spanish mackerel, is also used.

sen.j: 鯖の場合はしめさばと同じである。
sen.e: The kizushi of chub mackerel is the same as what is called shimesaba (salted and vinegared mackerel).
The kizushi of chub mackerel is the same as what is called shimesaba (salted and vinegared mackerel).
The kizushi of chub mackerel is the same as what is called shimesaba (salted and vinegared mackerel).

sen.j: 概ね西日本できずし、東日本でしめさばと言うようである。
sen.e: It seems that people in western Japan usually call it kizushi, while most people in eastern Japan call it shimesaba.
It seems that people in western Japan usually call it kizushi, while most people in eastern Japan call it shimesaba.
It seems that people in western Japan usually call it kizushi, while most people in eastern Japan call it shimesaba.

sen.j: 寿司という名前だが飯無しの切り身で食べるのが普通である。
sen.e: The name kizushi literally means fresh sushi but usually refers to the sliced fish served without rice.
Although the name is referred as a sushi, it usually refers to the sliced fish served without rice.
sen.cmt: 文脈より修正しました。
sen.e: Although the name is referred as a sushi, it usually refers to the sliced fish served without rice.

sen.j: 切り身はさらに切り込みを入れる場合もあり、刺身やたたきと同様醤油をかけ食べる。
sen.e: The sliced fish, with further cuts sometimes being made through the skin, is eaten with soy sauce, as are sliced raw fish and lightly roasted fish.
The slices, with further cuts sometimes made through the skin, are eaten with soy sauce, as are sashimi (sliced raw fish) or tataki (seared outside fish).
sen.cmt: 文をよりスムースに修正しました。「刺身」と「たたき」は説明をよりスムースするため補いました。「たたき」は、"seared"での記述がウェブ上で多く見られるのでそのようにしました。
sen.e: The slices, with further cuts sometimes made through the skin, are eaten with soy sauce, as are sashimi (sliced raw fish) or tataki (seared outside fish).

sen.j: ワサビ、生姜などを添える場合もある。
sen.e: Wasabi and ginger may be served with the kizushi.
Wasabi and ginger may be served with the kizushi.
Wasabi and ginger may be served with the kizushi.

sen.j: 飯に乗せて寿司としたものはきずしずし、鯖寿司、バッテラなどになる。
sen.e: Sushi having the kizushi on the top of the rice is called kizushi zushi, saba zushi, or battera.
Sushi, having the kizushi on the top of rice is called kizushi zushi, saba zushi, or battera.
sen.cmt: カンマを挿入しました。the rice→rice と修正しました。
sen.e: Sushi, having the kizushi on the top of rice is called kizushi zushi, saba zushi, or battera.

sen.j: 一般的な作り方は頭を落とし内臓を取って三枚下ろしにした魚を塩に一晩程度浸け、そのあと酢で洗う。
sen.e: The most common way to make the kizushi is to cut the head off, clean and fillet the fish, which is pickled in salt for about one night and then rinsed in vinegar.
The most common way to make the kizushi is, to cut the head off, clean and fillet the fish, which is pickled in salt for about one night and then rinsed in vinegar.
sen.cmt: カンマを挿入しました。
sen.e: The most common way to make the kizushi is, to cut the head off, clean and fillet the fish, which is pickled in salt for about one night and then rinsed in vinegar.

sen.j: 浸ける時間などや塩、酢の量は各種流儀があるようである。
sen.e: The time the sliced fish is cured in salt and the amount of salt and vinegar seem to vary depending on the recipe.
The length of the time to pickle, and the amount of salt and vinegar for the fish seem to vary depending on each recipes.
The length of the time to pickle, and the amount of salt and vinegar for the fish seem to vary depending on each recipes.

sen.j: 元々は保存食であり、日本海でとれた鯖を都に運ぶために塩漬けにしたのが始まりとされる。
sen.e: The kizushi is said to have originally been the preserved food and originated in an attempt to cure the mackerel caught in the Japan Sea in salt in order to take it to the imperial capital.
The kizushi is said to have originally been a preserved food and originated in that, the mackerel caught in the Japan Sea was cured in order to take it to the imperial capital.
sen.cmt: the→a,文中ほどよりスムースに修正しました。
sen.e: The kizushi is said to have originally been a preserved food and originated in that, the mackerel caught in the Japan Sea was cured in order to take it to the imperial capital.

sen.j: 若狭湾から京都へ至る道を若狭街道といい、その通称が鯖街道であった。
sen.e: The Wakasa Kaido Road, connecting Wakasa Bay to Kyoto, was dubbed the Saba Kaido Road (Mackerel Road).
The Wakasa Kaido Road, connecting Wakasa Bay to Kyoto, was commonly called the Saba Kaido Road (Mackerel Road).
sen.cmt: dubbed→commonly called と修正しました。
sen.e: The Wakasa Kaido Road, connecting Wakasa Bay to Kyoto, was commonly called the Saba Kaido Road (Mackerel Road).

sen.j: なお、生寿司を「なまずし」と読んだ場合は通常の寿司を指す。
sen.e: The Chinese characters for kizushi are also read "namazushi," in which case it refers to the ordinary sushi.
The Chinese characters for kizushi are also read "namazushi," in which case it refers to the ordinary sushi.
The Chinese characters for kizushi are also read "namazushi," in which case it refers to the ordinary sushi.
